The interaction between ethanol molecules to produce 1-butanol over surfaces of Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al oxides derived from hydrotalcites (HT) was studied experimentally and computationally. For Mg/Al catalyst, the insertion of Al in the MgO lattice generates a selectivity of 11.7 % for 1-butanol and of 5.8 % for diethyl ether at 300 °C, indicating the importance of the presence of acid sites for dehydration. For Cu-Mg/Al catalyst, Cu2+ cations have been structural substituted, instead of superficial substituted, exhibiting the highest selectivity for 1-butanol at 250 °C (16.5 %). The inclusion of copper increases the number of acid-base pairs, which are important in the dehydrogenation of ethanol molecules, the aldol condensation of acetaldehyde molecules and the subsequent steps to get 1-butanol. According to DFT results, the presence of copper favors the adsorption of ethanol on the surface, weakening the Cα-Hα bond of the molecule, contributing to the formation of acetaldehyde. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Butanol Ethanol transformation Hydrotalcite Mixed oxides Guerbet reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ethanol is a primary alcohol obtained from either a petrochemical route or biomass [1]. One of the most important derivatives obtained from ethanol is 1-butanol [2], which is easily mixed with all common organic solvents, such as glycols, ketones, and alcohols [3]. 1-Butanol is known as a platform molecule that, compared to ethanol, has a greater number of applications in the industry; since, it is used to obtain various derived, formulated, and consumer products; and its physicochemical properties give it enormous potential as a fuel [3–5]. At the industry, 1-butanol is mainly used for the manufacture of paints, coatings, and inks, among others [6–9]. 1-butanol has better physicochemical properties as a fuel than ethanol since it has a higher energy density (29.2 MJ/L to butanol vs. 19.6 MJ/L to ethanol), low solubility in water (73 g/L vs. complete solubility), low heat of vaporization (0.43 MJ/kg vs. 0.92 MJ/kg), similar octane number (96) to gasoline (90-94) versus ethanol (129) and a cetane index similar to diesel (40-55 to butanol, 51.7 to diesel and 8.5 to ethanol). All these properties make it a suitable candidate for mixing with both gasoline and diesel [10]. Currently, two common processes have been used to produce 1-butanol: hydroformylation (OXO, the most common) and the aceto-butyl-ethyl fermentation (ABE). However, both processes have drawbacks; for example, the ABE process results in a low yield, difficult separation of the products, and high toxicity of the solvents [11–13]; while, the OXO process uses carbon monoxide (toxic and harmful to the environment and humans) and propylene (highly flammable), OXO also needs high reaction pressure (30 MPa), and uses two different catalysts (cobalt or rhodium in the first step and nickel in the second step), making it an expensive process with low profitability [14,15]. Due to these disadvantages, the Guerbet reaction has emerged as a cleaner alternative for producing 1-butanol, representing a challenge to the academy and industry [16–18]. The Guerbet reaction is an endothermic process, characterized by the conversion of ethanol to 1-butanol and higher alcohols in the presence of a catalyst and under moderate pressure and temperature compared to the OXO process [19]. This overall reaction occurs in four stages: dehydrogenation, aldol condensation, dehydration and hydrogenation to finally obtain 1-butanol [20–22]. In this reaction, both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts can be used [23–25]. Due to the many disadvantages associated with the use of homogeneous catalysts, such as difficulty or no separation at the end of the reaction and greater environmental contamination, heterogeneous catalysts have become an interesting option in recent years [26,27]. Zeolites, mixed oxides, hydroxyapatite (HAP), and supported metallic catalysts, which have extensively studied due to their stability and reproducibility [21,28,29], are among the main heterogeneous catalysts studied for the Guerbet reaction[[21,28,29]. Moreover, Mg/Al mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites are the most promising catalysts due to their large number of active sites, acid/base properties, ease to synthetize, and low production cost [30–32]. Hydrotalcites (HT) are double layer hydroxides (LDH) used as precursors of mixed oxides obtained through calcination [33–35]. These oxides have high chemical stability as well as good thermal stability and a series of modulable acid/base properties due to the composition of their precursors [36–38]. To obtain the mixed oxide the HT are decomposed at a temperature of 500 °C. This temperature allows the following processes dehydration, dehydroxylation, and decarbonization, to finally become a mixed oxide of Mg-O-Al [39–44]. However, temperatures above 550 °C could generate the spinel phase [42]. The effect of the chemical composition, the hydrotalcite synthesis method, the calcination temperature, and the reaction conditions on the conversion of ethanol toward 1-butanol have been published in recent years [45–51]. Recent studies have examined the catalytic activity of mixed oxides in the presence of structural copper. For instance, Mück et al. reported a 4.6 % yield of 1-butanol using a microflow reactor with and a temperature range of 280-350 °C [48]. Similarly, Frolich et al. produced higher alcohols, achieving 74 % ethanol conversion and 29 % selectivity to butanol using a flow reactor at a pressure of 10 MPa over 128 ho at temperatures ranging from 280-350 °C [51]. Marcu et al. and Benito et al. reported 1-butanol yields of 1.6 % at 200 °C and 15.0 % at 230 °C, respectively, both using an autoclave reactor with reaction times of 5 and 6 hours [49,50]. All the mentioned catalysts were pre-activated using H2 to reduce the metal cations. In this work, we analyze the substitution of 10 wt. % Mg2+ with Cu2+ in the catalyst structure and how this replacement affects its properties, such as the acid-base behavior, adsorption of the reactants, and selectivity toward 1-butanol. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Cu(NO3)2· 3H2O (99.5 %, Panreac), Mg(NO3)2· 6H2O (98 %, Emsure), Al(NO3)3· 9H2O (98.5 %, Panreac), Na2CO3 (99.9 %, Panreac) and NaOH (> 99.0 %, Merck) were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts Mg/Al 3/1 hydrotalcite (HT) was synthesized by a coprecipitation method; for this purpose, aqueous solutions of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were mixed at a molar ratio of Mg/Al 3/1. Subsequently, mix nitrate solution was added dropwise to a Na2CO3 solution at constant stirring and temperature (60 °C). pH was regulated at 9.5-10.5 with the addition of 2 M NaOH. The resulting mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, microwaved for 1 h at 640 Watts, and then centrifuged. The as-synthesized solid was washed with deionized water until a pH of 7 was reached, dried at 80 °C for 24 h, ground, and sieved through an N° 100 mesh. HT was calcined at 500 °C (2 °C/min) for 6 h. The magnesium oxide (MgO) and Cu-Mg/Al hydrotalcite (Cu-Mg/Al) syntheses were carried out similarly. The synthesis of Cu-Mg/Al with a molar ratio of M2+/M3+ = 3 was carried out by replacing 10 wt.% Mg2+ ions with Cu2+ using the copper nitrate trihydrate Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as a precursor. Magnesium oxide was obtained by coprecipitation of magnesium hydroxide using magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O) as a precursor. Oxides were obtained as previously described. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of all the catalysts were recorded at room temperature on a Panalytical X´PertPRO MPD diffractometer using copper Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). Each sample was scanned in the 2θ range within 10 to 90° with a step size of 0.02 and 10 s per step. Diffractograms were analyzed using X'pert Highscore Plus software. The crystallite size and cell parameters were determined using the Scherrer equation. The chemical composition was analyzed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) coupled to an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) probe (TESCAN model LYRA3 with an X-Max detector and Aztec Software 3.3 SP1). Three different acceleration voltages (HVs) for the same area (5, 10, and 20 kV) were employed for Cu-Mg/Al sample, while an acceleration voltage of 10kV was employed for Mg/Al sample. A cross-section analysis was done for the Cu-Mg/Al sample to determine copper's incorporation in the structure. In this procedure, a protective layer of platinum was deposited onto the sample surface to protect the material from the ion beam; subsequently, the material was sectioned with a focused ion beam (FIB) of gallium ions, allowing the penetration of the mixed oxide to approximately 15 μm from the surface toward the interior to obtain the cut cross-section of the solid. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were obtained at -196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The solids were degassed at 300 °C for 4 h. The specific surface area was determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model, and the pore distribution was determined using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model due to the great ability of this model to describe mesoporous materials [52]. The acid and basic properties were measured by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) and NH3 (NH3-TPD), respectively, using an Autochem II 2920 Micromeritics® equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the analysis, ca. 200 mg of the sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. The sample was pre-treated under argon at 500 °C for 60 min, cooled to 50 °C, and exposed to 5 % CO2/He or 5 % NH3/He for 60 min. Then, the physisorbed CO2 or NH3 was removed by flushing with argon at 50 °C. Desorption was measured by heating the sample from 50 °C to 500 °C at 10 °C/min. The number of basic or acid sites was calculated by deconvoluting the CO2 or NH3 peaks with the software of the instrument, assuming Gaussian and logarithmic distributions and, using a calibration curve prepared with gas mixtures (5 % CO2/He or 5 % NH3/He) and pure He, this curve was prepared using mass flow controllers to obtain different CO2 or NH3 concentrations. 2.4 Catalytic testing Catalytic tests were carried out in a Parr® stainless steel batch reactor using 3 wt. % of catalyst vs. absolute ethanol. The catalysts were calcined before the reaction to remove physisorbed water and CO2. N2 was used to purge the reactor. The reactions were carried out at 250 and 300 °C and autogenous pressure with 300 rpm of stirring for 6 h. Liquid products were analyzed using a Shimadzu GC-17A gas chromatograph equipped with an FID detector and a DB-WAX capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm) and ethanol, acetaldehyde, ethyl acetate, diethyl ether, and 1-butanol standards were used for retention time comparison and quantification. Diffractograms of the Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al HTs exhibited seven peaks at approximately 12, 24, 36, 39, 47, 61 and 63 (2θ°), which are characteristic of the layered double hydroxide (HT) with ICSD 98-008-1963 (Fig. 2a). Unit cell dimension a was calculated using the plane (1 1 0), whereas c was obtained using the lattice plane (0 0 3), the substitution of magnesium cations by copper cations promoted small changes in the lattice constants of hydrotalcite, this is due to the ionic sizes of Mg2+ and Cu2+ are almost identical: 72 pm and 73 pm, respectively. Nevertheless, the slight increase in parameter c, indicates a small increment in the interlaminar space in solid Cu-Mg/Al compared to Mg/Al. The crystallite size was calculated using the most intense signal and Scherrer's equation (results are shown in Table 1), there are no statistical differences among the solids. Comparing XRD results (Fig. 2a and 2b), it is possible to see that there are no residual peaks corresponding to the HT phase on magnesium oxide and mixed oxides diffractograms. It was observed that some magnesium oxide peaks are characteristic of the low crystallinity periclase phase. Mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites exhibited four peaks at approximately 38, 42, 61, and 78 (2θ°), associated with the periclase phase of MgO (ICSD 00-045-0946), and one peak at approximately 37 (2θ°), associated with the spinel phase (MgAl2O4, ICSD 98-016-1056). No phases containing aluminum or copper were detected, indicating that Al3+ and Cu2+ were highly dispersed in each of the structures. Finally, a slight shift is presented on mixed oxides compared to magnesium oxide, this shift is attributed to the low crystallinity of the MgO phase due to the inclusion of aluminum in the structure [60,61]. EDX spectra, which display the composition of mixed oxides, are shown in Figures S2 and S3. The elemental composition of the Mg/Al catalyst shows a weight percentage (wt. %) of 40.94 % for Mg and 14.66 % for Al. Conversely, for Cu-Mg/Al, the wt. % were 33.37 %, 13.45 % and 10.80 %, for Mg, Al, and Cu, respectively. Table 2 illustrates the molar ratio of Mg/Al in the materials and the Cu weight percentage in Cu-Mg/Al, showing that substitution of Mg2+ for Cu2+ was made in a 10 %. Furthermore, additional Cu-Mg/Al mixed oxide analyses were performed at three different acceleration voltages (HVs) (5, 10, and 20 kV). For all cases, the percentage of copper in the mixed oxide remains constant, suggesting a structural substitution (Table S1). To verify this observation a Focused Ion Beam (FIB) - SEM was employed to determine the composition of the cross section. The element distribution EDX maps for Cu, Mg, Al, show that all elements are homogenously localized over all the cross section (Fig. 3 a-b) and the EDX linear analysis from the surface to 15 µm inside the catalyst does not show a big variation in the atomic percentage (Fig. 3c). Therefore, copper has been structurally substituted in the catalyst. Morphology analyses of Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al mixed oxides derived from HT were studied using SEM. Notice that the solids do not present a defined morphology; however, typical superimposed layers are observed in both cases (Fig. 4 ); the specific surface areas (SBET) for Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al were evaluated, showing a characteristic SBET value for this kind of solids (216 and 240 m2/g, respectively) (Table 3 ) [2,62]. The isotherms obtained from mixed oxides exhibit a behavior corresponding to type IV according to IUPAC classification, indicating mesoporous solids (Fig. 5 ). According to the IUPAC classification [63,64], the hysteresis of the Cu-Mg/Al mixed oxide catalyst is H3, typically of mesoporous materials, with parallel adsorption and desorption branches; since the adsorption on the solid occurs in unconnected mesopores, with a relatively narrow pore size distribution. H3 hysteresis indicates the presence of pores generated by flaky particles associated with hydrotalcites [64,65]. The Mg/Al mixed oxide presents an H5 hysteresis loop, which is distinguished by its almost triangular shape, with a break at relative pressures of 0.9 to 0.95. This brake is associated with the porosity in restricted environments due to poor geometry, such as a combination of open and restricted pore geometries or networks. This geometry is related to the abrupt closure of the desorption isotherm [64,66]. The replacement of magnesium cations by copper cations reduces the total surface area of the hydrotalcite, as evidenced in Table 3, since the decrease of the mesopore areas is not compensated for the increase of the micropore areas. Finally, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD were carried out to determine basic and acid sites of MgO, Mg/Al, and Cu-Mg/Al mixed oxides. Weak strength basic sites (∼ 109 °C) are characterized by the formation of bicarbonate species, when CO2 is adsorbed on a surface hydroxyl group (Brønsted type), while medium strength basic sites (∼238 °C) are characterized by adsorbed CO2 as a bidentate carbonate on an acid‒base pair Mg2+-O2- or Al3+ -O2- (Lewis type) [67,68]. Temperatures associated with a strong adsorption of CO2 are found near 700 °C [68]. Quantification of basic sites is shown in Table 4 . Cu-Mg/Al and Mg/Al oxides have a higher number of basic sites compared to MgO. MgO is a bulk rigid solid with no laminar structure, therefore its specific surface area and acid-base properties must be deficient. The behavior of weak-medium strength basic solid exposed by MgO agrees with the results given by Tanabe et al [68]. However, mixed oxides are derived from a stacked structure with a high surface area, and then more adsorption sites. When solids are compared, Mg/Al oxide is a stronger basic oxide but Cu2+ slightly increases the quantity of medium basic sites; thus, increasing the distribution of Cu-O-Al acid-base pairs. NH3-TPD results on MgO show a small quantity of weak and medium acid sites. These sites are associated with the adsorption of NH3 over Lewis acid sites (metallic cations). Strong acid sites correspond to groups that enable the dissociation of ammonia into NH2 (adsorbed over metallic cations), and H (abstracted by O2- atoms) [69]. The insertion of Cu2+ into the structure increases the concentration of acid sites, and its presence promotes the presence of strong acid sites. In this way, the presence of a high number of acid sites on Cu-Mg/Al mixed oxides favors dehydration step on the Guerbet reaction. In summary, XRD and SEM-EDX experiments revealed that Cu2+ cations replace Mg2+ in the structure, without affecting the structural or morphological properties of the mixed oxides. This is depicted in Fig. 4 and Table 3, which show the typical superimposed layers and specific surface area of the mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites. Furthermore, the insertion of copper enhanced the acid-base behavior of the solid, leading to an increase in medium-strength basic sites and the formation of strong acid sites. These results enable us to understand the chemical environment in which the reaction was carried out. To increase the comprehension, at atomistic level, of the catalyst's chemical environment and the interaction between the catalyst and the ethanol, a computational analysis was done. To simulate the solid characteristics mentioned above, various cells were built. Fig. 6 a shows the models of the MgO and Mg/Al fragments, and one of the Cu-Mg/Al conformations. As mentioned, cationic vacancies are necessary to preserve the electroneutrality of Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al fragments. The correspondent Molecular Electrostatic Potential maps (MEPs) can be found in Fig. 6b, which were generated to elucidate the preferential adsorption points on the mixed oxide. These maps show the electrostatic potential built by a specific electronic density within a molecule. Blue areas indicate a low charge density area, where the solid is more likely to accept the electronic density, such as the OOH from the ethanol, creating an optimal adsorption site over Mg cations; while areas with a high electron density (red areas) are needed to interact with HOH, these zones correspond to oxygens with low coordination. The optimized complex geometries in Fig. 6C are evidence of this trend. Furthermore, it is possible to affirm that the acidic properties of the Mg and basic properties of the oxygen in the solid (OS) were enhanced by the insertion of Al and Cu (see Figure S4-5), which influenced the generation of surface defects, creating sites with low-coordinate oxygens and, therefore, a greater ability to donate charge. 3.2 Analysis of ethanol adsorption and transformation over MgO and mixed oxide catalysts A quantitative measure of the adsorption energy was estimated through Eq. (4), which represents the first initial step in the conversion of ethanol to other products. These energies reflect the ability of the catalyst to adsorb ethanol and are related to the experimental conversion outcomes. Table 5 shows that adsorption on mixed oxides is favored compared to MgO, particularly in Cu-Mg/Al oxide in conformation 1. Moreover, the results exposed in Table S2 indicate that in the case of the complex formed by Cu-Mg/Al oxide in conformation 5 (Figure S1), adsorption was disadvantageous. This behavior is explained by the replacement of Mg2+ by a Cu2+ in the position where ethanol is adsorbed, weaking the interaction with ethanol molecules. Consequently, this binding energy is even more positive compared to MgO oxide (Table S2). Therefore, the high electronic density of Cu2+ disfavors the direct interaction with OOH but increases the adsorption of ethanol in a vicinal Mg2+ position probably due to a π back donation effect, which will be better explained later in the text. Experimental data concerning conversion and selectivity are shown in Fig. 7 . Experiments were carried out at two different temperatures, 250 °C (bars to the left) and 300 °C (bars to the right); where conversion (right axis) and selectivity (left axis) are expressed in percentage. In this way, experimental results related to conversion are consistent with the computational data, since mixed oxides are a better catalyst than MgO oxide. Such behavior is shown in Fig. 7, where the conversion percentages are greater using the copper mixed oxide and vary between 55 and 75 %. Also, it is possible to observe that, concerning the production of 1-butanol, MgO has a selectivity of 0.9 % at 250 °C and 6.5 % at 300 °C. The low selectivity of this catalyst is related to the low proportion of basic and acid sites, preventing ethanol adsorption, which is confirmed by the calculated adsorption energies. These results highlight the importance not only the strong basic sites but also acid‒base pairs in ethanol transformation, particularly in the formation of 1-butanol. In this context, the basic site of the acid‒base pair plays a crucial role in abstracting the hydrogen from the O-H group, while the acidic site containing the ethoxy group, facilitates the aldolic condensation and subsequent reactions (Scheme 1 a) [70]. The reaction mechanism for 1-butanol production proceeds as follows: two adjacent acid‒base pairs adsorb two molecules of ethanol and forms two molecules of acetaldehyde, then an aldolic condensation between these two molecules leads to the formation of 3-hydroxybutanal. Medium-strength basic sites are essential for proton abstraction from alpha carbon (see Scheme 1b), promoting the dehydration of 3-hydroxybutanal (Scheme 1c). Finally, successive hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde (2-butenal) occurs, passing through butyraldehyde until 1-butanol is formed, as shown in Scheme 1d [45]. Fig. 7 shows that the Mg/Al catalyst exhibited enhanced selectivity toward 1-butanol at 300 °C (11.7 %) compared to 250 °C (4.5 %). The presence of Al3+ cations in its structure, results in greater Lewis's acidity, facilitating ethanol adsorption for subsequent dehydrogenation and condensation to form 1-butanol. Similarly, it displayed selectivity toward diethyl ether of 2.1 and 5.8 % at 250 and 300 °C, respectively. For the formation of diethyl ether, two ethanol molecules adsorb on an acid‒base pair and a vicinal acid site (Scheme 2 ). First, a molecule of ethanol (I) is adsorbed only through the oxygen of the OH group onto a Lewis acid site, inducing a slightly positive charge on the alpha carbon. Then, the second ethanol molecule (II) is adsorbed via the -OH group in an acid‒base pair. The adsorption of the hydrogen atom on the surface weakens the O-H bond of molecule II, causing H to donate its charge to oxygen, rendering it with a certain nucleophilic character. This capacity, coupled with weakening of the C-O bond in molecule I, cause a nucleophilic attack, where the oxygen of the ethanol molecule (II) attacks the alpha carbon of the ethanol molecule (I), resulting in the breaking of the C-O bond, a dehydration and formation of diethylether. The selectivity toward diethylether arises from the presence of Al3+ in the structure, which significantly increases the number of acid sites and facilitates the ethanol adsorption. At 250 °C, the Cu-Mg/Al catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity toward 1-butanol (16.2 %), accompanied with other discernible products such as acetaldehyde (4.1 %), and ethyl acetate (4.9 %). The electronic properties of copper play an essential role in both abstracting hydrogen from the -OH of ethanol and facilitating the dehydrogenation of ethanol's alpha carbon, leading to the transformation into acetaldehyde. Additionally, copper facilitates aldol condensation while preventing dehydration and the formation of diethyl ether. Copper, being an electron rich metal, exhibits π back donation to C-H species with similar π symmetry. The cation back donates to the antibonding sigma Cα-Hα bond of ethanol, weakening it until it is ultimately cleaved. It is notable that on the Cu-Mg/Al catalysts, an increase in the reaction temperature diminished the conversion and selectivity, this could be associated with the fact that a temperature near 300 °C promotes the reduction to Cu+. This reduction is favored by the H2 atmosphere generated by the first Guerbet reaction step (see Figure S5). Comparatively, the Cu-Mg/Al catalyst demonstrated two distinct effects compared to the Mg/Al catalyst, regardless of temperature. First, the incorporation of copper in the structure decreases the formation of dehydration products such as diethyl ether. The presence of structural Cu2+ endows this catalyst, enhancing dehydrogenation/hydrogenation capacity as evidenced by the improvement of the production of acetaldehyde, ethyl acetate and 1-butanol. Ethyl acetate is formed through two closely adsorbed ethanol molecules on an acid‒base pair and an acid site. First, a molecule of ethanol (I) is adsorbed onto a Lewis acid site, causing the alpha carbon to become slightly positive. Then, the second ethanol molecule (II) is adsorbed through the OH group in an acid‒base pair (Scheme S1). Liquid products such as 1-Butanol, acetaldehyde, crotonaldehyde, diethyl ether, and alcohols of higher molecular weight (Table S3), as well as gas products with lower molecular weight, were identified, but only the most abundant products were quantified by gas chromatography. The ability to eliminate the alpha hydrogen of ethanol, crucial in the synthesis route for producing 1-butanol via dehydrogenation (Scheme 1), was computationally evaluated using Bader's atoms in molecules (AIM) theory. This analysis focused on three complexes: ethanol and MgO, Mg/Al, and the most favorable conformation of Cu-Mg/Al. AIM theory characterizes intermolecular interactions based on electronic density behavior, identifying four types of critical points (CPs): (A) bonding critical points (BCP) (3, -1); (B) ring critical points (RCP) (3,+1), commonly found in ring structures like benzene; (C and D) CP types (3, 3) and (3, +3), corresponding to nuclear positions and the electron density of cage-shaped molecules, respectively [52,53]. CPs were observed between adjacent oxygen (OAd) to the Mg and the alpha hydrogen (see Fig. 1) in two of the three complexes, namely the Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al systems (see Figure S6). The CP type corresponds to one BCP, which implies the bond formation between two atoms. To assess the effect of this interaction on Cα-Hα bonding, the electronic density of this bond was calculated, and the results showed that for the complex with Mg/Al oxide, the electronic density was 0.8973 |e|/Bohr3, while for the Cu-Mg/AlO complex the value was 0.7683 |e|/Bohr3. Thus, the adsorption of Cu-Mg/Al oxide not only enhances the conversion, but also is more liable to dehydrogenate ethanol molecules, in agreement with the experimental results. According to F. de Souza. [49], the dehydrogenation product corresponds to the generation of acetaldehyde (Ac), which is the next upgraded ethanol during the synthesis of 1-butanol (see Scheme 1). In this way, the energy of the catalyst and acetaldehyde complex (Ac-complex) was calculated for MgO, Mg/Al, and one conformation of Cu-Mg/Al. The energy diagrams for the reactants (ethanol and mixed fragment oxide), the ethanol complex and the Ac-complex are presented in Fig. 8 , where it is possible to note that copper mixed oxide is the most appropriated option among the studied catalysts. In Fig. 7, a clear trend is observed with the MgO and Mg/Al catalysts, showing an increase in the selectivity of 1-butanol as the temperature increases. This result is associated with the fact that at 300 °C, the speed of the dehydrogenation process increases, which is the slow step of the reaction, and with this, the subsequent processes improve, until 1-butanol is obtained. On the other hand, the Cu-Mg/Al solid decreased its selectivity toward 1-butanol when the temperature increases from 250 to 300 °C; this effect can be associated to the partial reduction of Cu2+ to Cu1+, which occurs at 300 °C and, consequently, the dehydrogenation/hydrogenation capacity decreases. This was evidenced since the production of products such as acetaldehyde, ethyl acetate and 1-butanol decreased; however, XPS experiments must be performed to demonstrate this hypothesis. It is possible to notice that presence of Cu on the solid enhances both selectivity and conversion of ethanol to 1-butanol, due to the increase on the acid sites that enable the dehydration following Guerbet reaction. Moreover, the insertion of Cu on the structure favored butanol production at low temperatures since its great capability to weaken Cα-Hα bond and causing the dehydrogenation of ethanol. However, adsorption of ethanol over Cu atoms is disfavored, resulting in a low conversion. For this purpose, it is important to ensure a high homogeneity of the distribution of copper in the structure that facilitates a synergic work between acid and basic sites. Selectivity achieved of 16.2 % is greater in comparison with most of the related investigations [48–51]. Additionally, this selectivity value was obtained without a previous activation process, this implies a reduction of the number of stages in the 1-butanol synthesis. 4 Conclusions Ethanol condensation to produce 1-butanol was successfully achieved using mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites as catalysts. Characterization techniques demonstrated the homogeneous distribution of Cu2+ in the structure of the solid Cu-Mg/Al. The presence of copper in the structure is crucial to obtain a high distribution of acid-base pairs and acid sites of medium and high strength, which together allow the adsorption of adjacent ethanol molecules leading to a dehydrogenation and a subsequent aldol condensation reaction to produce 1-butanol. Experimental and computational results suggested that the catalyst with copper is the most favorable for the adsorption of ethanol and for the dehydrogenation reaction. Copper is an electron rich cation and favors the adsorption of ethanol on the surface due to π back donation to C-H species with similar π symmetry. The cation back donates to the antibonding sigma Cα-Hα bond of ethanol, contributing to the formation of acetaldehyde which is the slow step of the reaction. Finally, it is worth saying that not only the 1-butanol, but all the products obtained employing these two catalysts are of great interest to the chemical industry. coredata.dc:description: The interaction between ethanol molecules to produce 1-butanol over surfaces of Mg/Al and Cu-Mg/Al oxides derived from hydrotalcites (HT) was studied experimentally and computationally. For Mg/Al catalyst, the insertion of Al in the MgO lattice generates a selectivity of 11.7 % for 1-butanol and of 5.8 % for diethyl ether at 300 °C, indicating the importance of the presence of acid sites for dehydration. For Cu-Mg/Al catalyst, Cu2+ cations have been structural substituted, instead of superficial substituted, exhibiting the highest selectivity for 1-butanol at 250 °C (16.5 %). The inclusion of copper increases the number of acid-base pairs, which are important in the dehydrogenation of ethanol molecules, the aldol condensation of acetaldehyde molecules and the subsequent steps to get 1-butanol. According to DFT results, the presence of copper favors the adsorption of ethanol on the surface, weakening the Cα-Hα bond of the molecule, contributing to the formation of acetaldehyde.
